text: since Friday's disputed presidential
election in Iran the country is
witnessing some of the largest street
demonstrations since the 1979 revolution
there have been anti-government protests
before in Iran particularly in 1999 and
2003 but those were centered on
university campuses and after three or
four days the government just sent in a
bunch of ICG vigilantes to break them up
and in one case they threw some students
out dormitory windows and they use clubs
and chains and bricks to sort of just
create sort of bloody mayhem around them
and of course they arrested hundreds of
students at the time President Mohammad
Khatami said that you know he didn't
want bloodshed and everybody should go
home and he kind of pushed the idea that
the regime was pushing those if they had
grievances they could you know address
them through the ballot box and this
time you know that message has failed
they tried the intimidating tactics
there's still people on the streets
they've tried saying that they're going
to do something about the election but
people are demanding a total recount and
I think there's three very important
differences this time first of all it's
not limited to students it cuts across
all economic classes and ages and it is
and they're huge the numbers are just on
a different scale of magnitude secondly
you know there's a there's a figure
around whom all the opposition is
rallying and that's Mir Hossein Mousavi
and mr. Mousavi has a history you know
he was prime minister in the 1980s when
there was a significant internal
opposition and there was a lot of
violence a couple of Iran analysts have
told me that between 10 and 20,000
people were killed in in sort of battles
at that time and so he's a veteran of
those so he is probably less timid about
you know they're being bloodshed
although he's called for people to stay
home so there isn't any people think
that you know he's just a harder
character and willing to be more
confrontational third the student
protests were sparked by fairly narrow
issues I mean one was a freedom of
speech issue when a newspaper was shut
down and the second was some controversy
over privatization of Education but
time it's really kind of it's a deeper
more fundamental issue about you know
our people's voices going to be heard
and trying to predict how this might in
Iran experts think it's going to be
difficult to reach any kind of
compromise because the opposition is
demanding a new presidential election
which is unlikely that the regime will
agree to that and they're basically
expecting kind of a tnmn moment when you
know the Chinese government rolled tanks
into the main square in Beijing to crush
a pro-democracy movement and Iran
experts are kind of anticipating
something similar in Tehran but with
that will also be crushed the idea that
the Islamic Republic is governed by a
popularly elected government
